comment._content: No Wikipedia article. German pilot apparently, he piloted the Rohrbach Ro II in 1923 (a seaplane, so not the plane in the picture)

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_endurance_record indicates that Landmann held the world record for length of flight very briefly, from June 29, 1914 until July 11, 1914

comment.author: 63316058@N05
comment._content: What a great project, thank you very much!

comment.author: 14651149@N00
comment._content:
Landmann is posing with an early Albatros, probably a B.I or B.II. 
Here's a B.I from San Diego Air & Space Museum Archives
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/sdasmarchives/4822763986/in/photostream/lightbox/]

and a photo of a B.II at the Heeresgeschichtliches Museum, Vienna, by flickr member jens.lilienthal
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/21532948@N04/5842774422/]

I think it's probably a version of the B.I, as the picture shows three sets of struts and the B.II had two sets per side. Engines varied in both types.
